Which of the following is the most common in the below condition
True regarding rhinitis medicamentosa and its associations is/are?

options.label: A
options.text: Long term use of steroids may be causative

options.label: B
options.text: Steroids may produce inflammation and hypertrophy of turbinates predisposing to this

options.label: C
options.text: Long term use of alpha adrenergic agonists may be causative

options.label: D
options.text: May be produced by cocaine sniffing

options.label: E
options.text: Only 5-10% may regress despite high-dose steroids

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Rhinitis medicamentosa
  • • The term indicates “persistent rhinitis induced by prolonged use of topical nasal decongestants (sympathomimetic amines and imidazoles)” (Task force definition). It is classified as “non-allergic rhinitis” (Old PGI MCQ) Mostly caused by topical sympathetic agents (e.g. alpha-adrenergic agonists like xylometazoline) May rarely be produced by cocaine sniffing and benzalkonium chloride. Persistent adrenergic stimulation producing refractoriness and rebound vasodilatation may be the pathophysiology After use of topical sympathetic agents beyond 3-5 days, there is rebound vasodilatation, nasal obstruction, edema, erythema and reduced efficacy of the drug. This congestion causes the patient to increase the frequency of application and the quantity applied, resulting in dependence on topical nasal decongestants Clinical rhinoscopic examination is non-specific, showing areas of red, thickened mucosa and dull zones It is treated by withdrawal of nasal drops, short course of systemic steroid therapy and in some cases, surgical reduction of turbinates, if they have become hypertrophied (Dhingra) Both topical and systemic steroids are effective in most cases. Topical antihistamines may also be tried (Sataloff”s)
  • • The term indicates “persistent rhinitis induced by prolonged use of topical nasal decongestants (sympathomimetic amines and imidazoles)” (Task force definition).
  • • It is classified as “non-allergic rhinitis” (Old PGI MCQ)
  • • Mostly caused by topical sympathetic agents (e.g. alpha-adrenergic agonists like xylometazoline)
  • • May rarely be produced by cocaine sniffing and benzalkonium chloride.
  • • Persistent adrenergic stimulation producing refractoriness and rebound vasodilatation may be the pathophysiology
  • • After use of topical sympathetic agents beyond 3-5 days, there is rebound vasodilatation, nasal obstruction, edema, erythema and reduced efficacy of the drug.
  • • This congestion causes the patient to increase the frequency of application and the quantity applied, resulting in dependence on topical nasal decongestants
  • • Clinical rhinoscopic examination is non-specific, showing areas of red, thickened mucosa and dull zones
  • • It is treated by withdrawal of nasal drops, short course of systemic steroid therapy and in some cases, surgical reduction of turbinates, if they have become hypertrophied (Dhingra)
  • • Both topical and systemic steroids are effective in most cases. Topical antihistamines may also be tried (Sataloff”s)

questions.text: Correct statement(s) regarding Caldwell-Luc operation?

options.label: B
options.text: Maxillary nerve block is not done since always done under GA

options.label: C
options.text: Done for biopsy in antral malignancy

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Caldwell-Luc operation
  • • Caldwell-Luc operation is a process of opening the maxillary antrum through canine fossa by sub-labial approach and dealing with the pathology inside the antrum. Can be done under LA.
  • • Indications:
  • • Chronic maxillary sinusitis with irreversible changes in the sinus mucosa. Removal of foreign bodies or root of a tooth. Dental cyst. Oroantral fistula. Suspected neoplasm in the antrum and its biopsy. Recurrent antrochoanal polyp. Fracture of maxilla or blow-out fractures of the orbit. As an approach to ethmoids (Horgan's transantral ethmoidectomy). Approach to pterygopalatine fossa for ligation of maxillary artery. Vidian neurectomy.
  • • Chronic maxillary sinusitis with irreversible changes in the sinus mucosa.
  • • Removal of foreign bodies or root of a tooth.
  • • Dental cyst.
  • • Oroantral fistula.
  • • Suspected neoplasm in the antrum and its biopsy.
  • • Recurrent antrochoanal polyp.
  • • Fracture of maxilla or blow-out fractures of the orbit.
  • • As an approach to ethmoids (Horgan's transantral ethmoidectomy).
  • • Approach to pterygopalatine fossa for ligation of maxillary artery.
  • • Vidian neurectomy.
  • • Complications:
  • • Complications:
  • • Post-operative bleeding. This can be controlled by nasal pack. Anaesthesia of the cheek due to stretching of infraorbital nerve. It may last for a few weeks or months. Anaesthesia of teeth. Injury to nasolacrimal duct. Sublabial fistula. Osteomyelitis of maxilla (rare).
  • • Post-operative bleeding. This can be controlled by nasal pack.
  • • Anaesthesia of the cheek due to stretching of infraorbital nerve. It may last for a few weeks or months.
  • • Anaesthesia of teeth.
  • • Injury to nasolacrimal duct.
  • • Sublabial fistula.
  • • Osteomyelitis of maxilla (rare).

questions.text: Tone decay test is used to identify which among the following condition (s)?

options.label: A
options.text: To test fatiguability of nerve in retrocochlear lesions

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Threshold tone decay test test
  • • It is a measure of nerve fatigue and is used to detect retrocochlear lesions. Normally, a person can hear a tone continuously for 60 seconds. Innerve fatigue, he stops hearing earlier. The threshold tone decay test is simple and is performed in the following manner:A tone of 4000 Hz is presented at 5 dB above the patient's threshold of hearing, continuously for a period of 60 seconds. If patient stops hearingearlier, intensity is increased by another 5 dB. The procedure is continued till patient can hear the tone continuously for 60 seconds, or no level exists above the threshold where tone is audible for full 60 seconds. The result is expressed as number of dB of decay. A decay more than 25 dBis diagnostic of a retrocochlear lesion.
